sub_topic: Determining the girth of a graph.
message_1: Consider a simple undirected graph G with 12 vertices and 15 edges. Determine the girth of G.
message_2:
The girth of a graph is the length of the shortest cycle in the graph. To determine the girth of G, we will use the following inequality:

girth(G) ≤ 2 * floor((2 * |E|) / |V|)

where |E| is the number of edges and |V| is the number of vertices in the graph.

In our case, |E| = 15 and |V| = 12. Plugging these values into the inequality, we get:

girth(G) ≤ 2 * floor((2 * 15) / 12)
girth(G) ≤ 2 * floor(30 / 12)
girth(G) ≤ 2 * floor(2.5)
girth(G) ≤ 2 * 2
girth(G) ≤ 4

So, the girth of G is at most 4. Now, we need to check if there exists a cycle of length 4 in the graph. Since the inequality holds, it is possible to have a cycle of length 4 in the graph. Therefore, the girth of G is 4.
